questions.text: The physiological processes concerned with the dynamics of aqueous humour are its production, drainage, and maintenance of intraocular pressure. Which of these is not true about its composition?

options.label: A
options.text: The normal aqueous production rate is 2.3 ml/min.

options.label: B
options.text: First of all, by ultrafiltration, most of the plasma substances pass out of the capillary wall and loose connective tissue.

options.label: C
options.text: The active transport of substances like sodium, chlorides, potassium, and bicarbonates across the non-pigmented ciliary epithelium results in an osmotic gradient leading to the movement of other plasma constituents into the anterior chamber by ultrafiltration and diffusion.

options.label: D
options.text: The active transport is brought about by the Na+-K+ activated ATPase pump, calcium and voltage gated ion channels, and carbonic anhydrase enzyme system.

questions.correct_answer: C. The active transport of substances like sodium, chlorides, potassium, and bicarbonates across the non-pigmented ciliary epithelium results in an osmotic gradient leading to the movement of other plasma constituents into the anterior chamber by ultrafiltration and diffusion.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The active transport of substances like sodium, chlorides, potassium, and bicarbonates across the non-pigmented ciliary epithelium results in an osmotic gradient leading to the movement of other plasma constituents into the anterior chamber by ultrafiltration and diffusion. Aqueous humour is derived from plasma within the capillary network of ciliary processes. The three mechanisms of diffusion , ultrafiltration, and secretion (active transport) play a part in its production at different levels. Substances that are actively transported include sodium, chlorides, potassium, ascorbic acid, amino acids, and bicarbonates. Active transport of these substances across the non pigmented ciliary epithelium results in an osmotic gradient leading to the movement of other plasma constituents into the posterior by ultrafiltration and diffusion. Sodium is primarily responsible for the movement of water into the posterior chamber.

Highyeild:

Aqueous humour is produced by the ciliary body, in uveoscleral route , it flows from posterior chamber through the pupil into the anterior chamber.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option : A . The normal aqueous production rate is 3 ml / min . Option : B . First of all during production, by ultrafiltration , most of the plasma substances pass out from the capillary wall and loose connective tissue. Thus, the plasma filtrate (dialysate) accumulates behind the pigmented and non pigmented epithelium of ciliary processes. Option : D . The active transport is brought about by the Na+-K+ activated ATPase pump , calcium and voltage gated ion channels, and carbonic anhydrase enzyme system. The tight junctions between the cells of the non pigment epithelium create part of the blood aqueous barrier. Certain substances are actively transported (secreted) across this barrier into the posterior chamber.

Extraedge:

Composition of Aqueous Humor Water 9% Protein concentration in aqueous is less than 1% of its plasma concentration. Glucose -75% of the plasma concentration Electrolyte - Sodium, bicarbonate and chloride Ascorbic acid

questions.text: Aqueous outflow active pump mechanisms are extremely important for the maintenance of IOP. Which of the following statements is not true about its mechanisms?

options.label: A
options.text: Aqueous outflow pump operates through oscillatory pressure transients caused by the ocular pulse, blinking, and eye movements.

options.label: B
options.text: Trabecular meshwork flexibility is essential for the aqueous outflow pump mechanism.

options.label: C
options.text: During cardiac diastole, the IOP is slightly decreased due to less blood flow to the choroidal vasculature.

options.label: D
options.text: Distention of the trabecular meshwork leads to the opening of aqueous valves.

questions.correct_answer: D. Distention of the trabecular meshwork leads to the opening of aqueous valves.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Distention of the trabecular meshwork leads to the opening of aqueous valves. During cardiac systole, the choroidal vasculature’s expansion leads to a transient rise in IOP. The aqueous pulse wave distends the trabecular meshwork (TM), forcing it outward against the Schlemm’s canal (SC) . As a consequence of this pressure, the aqueous valves close and aqueous from the SC are pushed through the collector channels in its outer wall into the aqueous veins.

Highyeild:

Physiology of Aqueous Production : Three physiological processes that contribute to the formation and chemical composition of aqueous humour are : ActiveSecretion: 70% Ultrafiltration: 20% Diffusion: 10 %

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Aqueous flow through the aqueous outflow system has long been considered a passive filter mechanism against the pressure gradient . However, recently it has been reported that an aqueous outflow system acts as a biomechanical pump. Aqueous outflow pumps operate through oscillatory pressure transients caused by the ocular pulse, blinking, and eye movements. Option: B . Trabecular meshwork actively moves outward and recoils back in response to the oscillatory pressure transients. Thus, trabecular meshwork flexibility is essential for the aqueous outflow pump mechanism. Option: C . Aqueous outflow pump systems are part of the vascular circulatory loop. During cardiac diastole the IOP is slightly decreased due to less blood flow to the choroidal vasculature. As a consequence, the trabecular meshwork is retracted inward, leading to a negative pressure inside the Schlemm’s canal and opening of the aqueous valves. This is followed by flow of aqueous inside the Schlemm’s canal.

Extraedge:

Composition of Aqueous Humor Water 9% Protein concentration in aqueous is less than 1% of its plasma concentration. Glucose -75% of the plasma concentration Electrolyte - Sodium, bicarbonate and chloride Ascorbic acid

questions.text: Aqueous outflow active pump mechanisms are extremely important for the maintenance of IOP. Which of the following statements about the production of aqueous humour is true? The active transport component is independent of intraocular pressure (IOP), whereas the ultrafiltration component decreases as IOP decreases. Aqueous humor formation is probably based on active ionic secretion with secondary passive fluid movement. Aqueous humor formation is entirely dependent on adenosine triphosphatase (ATPase) activity. Aqueous humor formation diminishes considerably during the night. Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2 and 4. A pressure-independent active transport mechanism and a Pressure-dependent ultrafiltration components both contribute to aqueous formation. 1 - The active transport component is felt to be the primary mechanism of aqueous production. 2 - This requires adenosine triphosphatase (ATPase) activity and creates a concentration gradient of certain ions, such as sodium chloride or bicarbonate, followed by a passive fluid movement. 3 - Ultrafiltration , which is independent of ATP, generally decreases as intraocular pressure (IOP) increases. 4 - A diurnal rhythm of aqueous flow has been found to exist, with flow being lower at night. Most people have their highest pressure during the morning hours.

Highyeild:

The Schlemm’s canal is a chamber with inlet and outlet valves.Pulse driven trabecular meshwork compression of Schlemm canal provides pulsatile aqueous outflow.An elastic energy equilibrium governs elastance and shear stress to maintain homeostasis.

Extraedge:

Trabecular outflow is increased by drugs (miotics, sympathomimetics), laser trabeculoplasty, and filtration surgery.

questions.text: Rate of aqueous formation influences IOP levels. The aqueous formation in turn depends upon many local and systemic factors. Which of the following factors is/are associated with a decrease in aqueous humour formation Inflammation Surgery Ocular trauma Age Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, 2, 3, and 4 Increasing age, ocular injury or inflammation, and ocular surgery can all decrease the rate of aqueous humor formation. The mean IOP increases after the age of 40 years, possibly due to reduced facility of aqueous outflow.

Highyeild:

Other factors influencing the aqueous humor formation are as below: IOP is equal between the sexes at ages 20–40 years. In older age groups, the increase in mean IOP with age is greater in females. Diurnal variation of IOP. Usually, there is a tendency for higher IOP in the morning and lower IOP in the late evening. This has been related to the diurnal variation in the levels of plasma cortisol. 'Normal eyes have a smaller fluctuation (< 5 mm of Hg) than glaucomatous eyes (>8 mm of Hg). Postural variations . IOP increases when changing from the sitting to the supine position. Seasonal variations . IOP is higher in winter months. Blood pressure. As such it does not have a long-term effect on IOP. However, prevalence of glaucoma is marginally more in hypertensives than the normotensives.

Random:

Explanation for all options: - Inflammation - associated with a fall in IOP. Surgery - associated with a fall in IOP. Ocular trauma - associated with a fall in IOP. Age - associated with a fall in IOP.

Extraedge:

Osmotic pressure of blood . An increase in plasma osmolarity (as occurs after intravenous mannitol, oral glycerol or in patients with uraemia) is associated with a fall in IOP, while a reduction in plasma osmolarity (as occurs with water drinking provocative tests) is associated with a rise in IOP.

questions.text: A 66-year-old male patient was referred with visual field loss and an open anterior angle. IOP is 21 mm Hg. Past medical history is significant for obstructive sleep apnoea syndrome. What is your initial impression?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Normal pressure glaucoma The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of normal pressure glaucoma . NTG , also referred to as low-tension or normal-pressure glaucoma, is usually regarded as a variant of POAG . The distinction between NTG and POAG is based on an epidemiologically derived range of normal IOP.

Highyeild:

NTG is characterized by: IOP consistently equals to or less than 21 mmHg on diurnal testing. Signs of optic nerve damage in a characteristic glaucomatous pattern. Visual field loss as damage progresses, consistent in pattern with the nerve appearance. An open anterior chamber angle. Obstructive sleep apnoea syndrome may be associated, perhaps via an effect on ocular perfusion

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Primary open angle glaucoma ( POAG ), is generally asymptomatic and patients may have nonspecific complaints such as: Headache Frequent changes in presbyopic correction Noticing a ‘blind spot’ or scotoma, especially if present in the inferior field Difficulty in dark adaptation To make a diagnosis of POAG, the presence of a normal, open angle should be confirmed by gonioscopy. The presence of optic nerve head changes suggestive of glaucomatous damage, including: A cup to disc ratio of more than 0.5 An asymmetry between the cup:disc ratio of two eyes of more than 0.2 Narrowing, notching, or pallor of the neuroretinal rim Option: C. Primary angle - closure disease includes a spectrum of conditions in which the peripheral iris moves forward to block the openings of the trabecular meshwork in an occludable angle, causing a rise of intraocular pressure. Females are more commonly affected by acute PACG, but in the asymptomatic or ‘creeping’ chronic variety, males and females are equally affected. Option: D. Progressive retinal nerve fibre defects not due to glaucoma, such as may occur in myopic degeneration and optic disc drusen. However, they can be differentiated due to the presence of typical features and presence of obstructive sleep apnoea syndrome as a risk factor.

Extraedge:

Systemic Associations : patient with NTG have been noted to have: A higher prevalence of hemodynamic crises Hypercoagulability Hypertension\hypotension Increased blood viscosity Elevated blood cholesterol and lipids Carotid artery disease Peripheral vasospasm Migraine

questions.text: A patient presents with glaucomatous changes. His IOP is 21 mm Hg. Which of the following conditions might be misdiagnosed as normal-tension glaucoma on initial evaluation of this patient? Parasellar tumors Methanol toxicity Arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AAION) Primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, 2, 3, and 4 A diagnosis of normal tension can be made only after other causes of optic neuropathy are eliminated. Although difficult to prove, the situation that may be the one most frequently misdiagnosed as “ normal - tension ” glaucoma is primary open - angle glaucoma ( POAG ), in which intraocular pressure (IOP) fluctuations have obscured the actual nature of the disease.

Highyeild:

In addition, there are other disorders that can feature pseudo glaucomatous optic nerve cupping , namely: Chiasmal compression , Arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy ( AAION ), Toxic optic neuropathies (such as methanol toxicity ), and Hypotension (“shock” optic neuropathy).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A, B, & C. Are not the correct options.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male was referred to the ophthalmology department due to an incidental finding of IOP being higher than normal as 23 mm Hg. He reports no changes in vision or other symptoms. All of the following are well-established early signs of glaucomatous damage except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Peripapillary atrophy Peripapillary atrophy is not considered an exclusive sign of early glaucomatous damage since other conditions such as ocular histoplasmosis or myopia can result in peripapillary atrophy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Focal enlargement of the cup appears as localized notching of the rim. The cup can become vertically oval if narrowing of the rim occurs at either the superior or inferior pole of the disc. Option: C. Splinter hemorrhages usually clear over several weeks but are often followed by localized notching of the rim. Option: D. Glaucomatous optic atrophy is associated with loss of axons in the nerve fibre layer, which can be best evaluated with red - free illumination .

questions.text: Which one of the following has not been suggested to be a possible pathophysiologic mechanism for optic neuropathy in patients suspected of having normal-tension glaucoma (low-tension glaucoma)?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Systemic hypercholesterolemia Systemic hypercholesterolemia has not been implicated in the pathophysiology of low - tension glaucoma . Low-tension glaucoma is defined as a form of glaucoma that closely mimics POAG, but IOP levels are within the normal rang, and the probable pathogenesis is vascular. It is a disease of elderly. more prevalent in the female population. positive family history .

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Normal - tension glaucoma is not one disease but rather a collection of disease processes characterized by characteristic glaucomatous visual field loss without elevated IOPs. Nocturnal systemic hypotension caused by excessively large late evening or bedtime doses of antihypertensive agents has recently been suggested to cause low-tension glaucoma on the basis of compromised optic nerve blood supply. Option: B & C: Vasospasm and shock may also compromise optic nerve blood supply.

questions.text: The individuals referred to as having ‘ocular hypertension’ (OHT) have an IOP>21 mm Hg. Which of the given factors does not significantly affect the occurrence of this pathologic phenomenon?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Myopia Some individuals may have an IOP >21 mmHg with open filtration angles and without detectable glaucomatous damage. These individuals are referred to as having ‘ocular hypertension’ (OHT) . Although it is suspected that myopic discs are more susceptible to glaucomatous damage at a lower IOP than emmetropic discs, myopia has been proven to be insignificant in various studies for the development of OHT.

Highyeild:

Complications of high myopia: Retinal Detachment Complicated cataract Vitreous Haemorrhage Choroidal haemorrhage

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Older age is associated with greater risk Option: C. The risk is greater in eyes with OHT and Central corneal thickness (CCT) SS<555 μm and lower in eyes with high CCT (>588 μm). This may be due to under- and overestimation of IOP, although it is more likely that associated structural factors, perhaps at the lamina cribrosa, might be involved. The CCT can be determined using optical imaging. Option: D. The greater the cup/disc (C/D) ratio, the higher the risk. This may be because an optic nerve head with a large cup is structurally more vulnerable, or it may be that early damage is already present.

questions.text: Raised IOP is an important risk factor in the development of glaucoma. Which of the following factors is a significant risk factor/red flag for this pathophysiology?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mitochondrial Function Raised IOP is an important risk factor in the development of glaucoma and can be modified with treatment. However, it is difficult to justify the treatment of all individuals with raised IOP because of the high prevalence of ocular hypertension . Thus, it is very important to identify the risk factors, or so called alarming red flags, to avoid the glaucomatous process. Recent studies have suggested a major role for angiopoietin - receptor tyrosine kinase signalling , lipid metabolism , mitochondrial function, and developmental processes as risk factors for elevated IOP.

Highyeild:

Diagnostic evaluation Regular eye examination - Ophthalmoscopy Slit lamp examination gonioscopy Tonometry

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. The risk is greater in eyes with OHT and central corneal thickness (CCT) of 555 μm and lower in eyes with a high CCT (>588 μm). This may be due to under- and overestimation of IOP, although it is more likely that associated structural factors, perhaps at the lamina cribrosa, might be involved. The CCT can be determined using optical imaging. Option: C. Pre-perimetric glaucoma refers to glaucomatous damage, usually manifested by a suspicious optic disc and/or the presence of retinal nerve fibre layer defects, in which no visual field abnormality has developed. Although the absence of visual field abnormalities does not pose an alarmingly great risk for the presence of glaucomatous damage; it should not completely negate the presence of glaucomatous damage. Option: D. Diurnal variations with high pressures are commonly recorded early in the morning or late at night. However, these variations only cause short-term changes, with values going back to the baseline ranges once the time passes.

Extraedge:

Management Medical management : beta blockers, miotics, carbonic anhydrase inhibitors, prostaglandin analogues Surgical management : argon laser trabeculoplasty, laser iridotomy, trabeculectomy.

questions.text: The given method is used to test. The image shown above depicts- Digital tonometry.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Intraocular Pressure The measurement of IOP (ocular tension) should be made in all suspected cases of glaucoma and in routine after the age of 40 years. A rough estimate of IOP can be made by digital tonometry . For this procedure, the patient is asked to look down, and the eyeball is palpated by index fingers of both the hands, through the upper lid, beyond the tarsal plate. One finger is kept stationary, which feels the fluctuation produced by the indentation of the globe by the other finger (Fig. 23.11). It is a subjective method and needs experience. When IOP is raised, fluctuation produced is feeble or absent and the eyeball feels firm to hard. When IOP is very low, the eye feels soft like a partially filled water bag .

Highyeild:

The exact measurement of IOP is done by an instrument called a tonometer . Indentation ( Schiotz tonometer ) and applanation (e.g. Goldmann's tonometer ) tonometers are frequently used • Normal IOP range is 10-21 mm of Hg with an average tension of 16 + 5.0 mm of Hg. Hypotony is labelled when IOP is less than 10 mm Hg. Causes of hypotony include ruptured globe, phthisis bulbi, retinal/choroidal detachment, iridocyclitis, ocular ischaemia, postoperative wound leak and traumatic ciliary body shut down.

Extraedge:

Glaucoma should be suspected when IOP is more than 21 mm of Hg and such patients should be thoroughly investigated.
